We want to return whether there is a win/tie/the board is full or not.
This function should return whether there is a win/tie/the board is full.
Assert equals asserts that two objects are equal.
If all spaces are occupied, and no player has met a win condition, then it is a tie.
If a space is occupied by a '-' then it is considered empty.
We can get the value of a square by accessing its coordinate in the array. For instance board[0][1] would return us the value of the item in (0,1) on the board.
We can check if multiple spaces have a common value by seeing if they are equal to each other. For instance board[0][0] == board[0][1] would return true if they had the same player mark.
Well I’m looking at the user stories and acceptance criteria, and ...
User Story 1/2/3 has us write a test for winning vertically/horizontally/diagonally.
User Story 1/2/3 says we need to test for a vertical/horizontal/diagonal win.
User Story 4 is for checking if the board is full using the isBoardFull method.
User Story 5 is about making sure that the players take turns.
We need to make a test for a tie game for User Story 6
For User Story 7, we need to write a test to check each method.
We’re going to want to write a test for a tie/vertical win/horizontal win/diagonal win/if the board is full.

Well for the horizontal test, we just have to place marks in a row, so at like (0,0), (1,0), and then (2,0).
Well for the horizontal test, we just have to place marks in a row, so at like (0,1), (1,1), and then (2,1).
Well for the horizontal test, we just have to place marks in a row, so at like (0,2), (1,2), and then (2,2).
Well for the vertical test, we just have to place marks in a column, so at like (0,0), (0,1), and then (0,2).
Well for the vertical test, we just have to place marks in a column, so at like (1,0), (1,1), and then (1,2).
Well for the vertical test, we just have to place marks in a column, so at like (2,0), (2,1), and then (2,2).
Well for the diagonal test, we just have to place marks on the diagonal, so at like (0,0), (1,1), and then (2,2).
Well for the diagonal test, we just have to place marks on the diagonal, so at like (2,0), (1,1), and then (2,0).
